column1: themessafterthemarty 162780869312 "2017-07-09 11:58:54 GMT" http://themessafterthemarty.tumblr.com/post/162780869312/heywriters-crazymusings-heywriters "heywriters: crazymusings:  heywriters:  mythcreantsblog:   If you read a classic story and it seems bad
column2: itâ€™s probably bad. Classics arenâ€™t exempt from the rules of storytelling because theyâ€™re old.   Classics are considered â€œclassicâ€ because they were the earliest example
column4: or the most popular early example of a specific style or genre. I find Oliver TwistÂ to be childish
column5: The Great GatsbyÂ to be unenjoyable
column6: Frankenstein and The Scarlet Letter needlessly dense
column8: and Pride & Prejudice containedÂ a lively amount of exclamation marks. However
column9: all of them were pioneers of modern fiction
column10: and without the foundation set by those works  none of us would be writing today. Itâ€™s smart to learn the origins of things
column11: smarter to improve upon them.  If youâ€™ve never read the 1818 Frankenstein (the 1831 is the typical
column12: much more dense one) Iâ€™d highly recommend it. Marry Shellyâ€™s husband Percy heavily revised it
column16: I think) and the themes are slightly different. I fell in love with Frankenstein through the 1818 version. For example
column17: Mary:Â  â€œNor were these my only visions. The raising of ghosts or devils was also a favorite pursuit and if I never saw any I attributed it rather to my own inexperience and mistakes than want of skill in my instructors.â€   Percy:Â â€œNor were these my only visions. The raising of ghosts or devils was a promise liberally accorded by my favorite authors
column18: the fulfillment of which I most eagerly sought; and if my incantations were always unsuccessful
column19: I attributed the failure rather to my own inexperience and mistakes
column20: than to a want of skill or fidelity in my instructors.â€     Wow
column21: thank you for the suggestion. You know
column22: I tried reading it again after high school and was put off by how dense it was. Perhaps the 1818 is what I read in high school
column23: but it makes total sense that Percy would do that. *eye roll* thatâ€™s soÂ Percy. " False text

themessafterthemarty 162771574007 "2017-07-09 04:48:17 GMT" http://themessafterthemarty.tumblr.com/post/162771574007/greenjimkirk-im-gonna-go-ahead-and-be-a-film "greenjimkirk:  Iâ€™m gonna go ahead and be a film snob and talk about why this is one of my favorite shots from TOS. (I could also say that itâ€™s one of my favorite scenes
column2: because the entire scene actually consists of a single shot.) We donâ€™t see a lot of bald expressions of emotion in film and television
column3: especially if that emotion is fear or sadness or vulnerability. Dramas will give us some tears
column4: but they always cut a way after a few seconds because a closeup of someone crying is deeply uncomfortable and most movies and TV shows arenâ€™t in the business of making their audiences uncomfortable. It just doesnâ€™t sell well. But in this scene the camera never looks away. It follows Spock as he sits down at the table
column5: and it circles him as he cries. But there are no cuts. We donâ€™t even get music to create some distance
column6: make it all a little more palatable; we just hear sobs and mumbled math equations. Itâ€™s absolutely excrutiating. It would be excruciating no matter who we were watching
column7: because we are so unaccustomed to seeing unadulterated emotion. And then thereâ€™s the fact that itâ€™s a man. And that itâ€™s Spock. Fifty years later and this is still one of the most daring filmmaking decisions Iâ€™ve ever seen on TV (I of course canâ€™t be exactly sure who made it
column8: but Iâ€™m assuming it was the director of the episode
column9: Marc Daniels). This shot lasts 1 minute and 45 seconds. Weâ€™re in the middle of space and in the middle of a high-stakes episode where the crew is going crazy and the ship is going to blow up or some shit and everyoneâ€™s lives are in danger
column10: but we pause 1 minute and 45 seconds to have an uncomfortably human moment with an alien who doesnâ€™t even want to be human
column11: and itâ€™s so awful and amazing. " False text
